J Tyler/ISP denies college wrongdoing re CalSTRs Audit findings

Friday, September 14th, 2007

FYI

In a public forum under “Superintendent President Report”, at the September 13, 2007 BOT meeting, Interim J Tyler, spoke publicly referencing inaccurate information reported by recent news articles concerning the CalSTRs Final Audit Report of May 2007 which faulted the college for the non-reporting of post-retirement earnings to CalSTRS of an Interim President Richard Giese hired through a third party contract with Maas Companies.

J.Tyler stated publicly that “he was setting the record straight concerning administrative perception of wrongdoing. The audit article is misinformation, the matter is between the employee and CalSTRS and is not a matter in which the college did any wrongdoing”

The audit is posted on this website and is now a public document. Note J.Tyler’s response to the auditor in the letter dated February 14, 2007 in which he states the college did not comply with the Education Code in these matters.

Audit Finding #1:
“The system of reporting did not follow Education Code Sections 23002 and 23005.”

Audit Finding #2:
“Under Education Code Section 22461, the College had a duty to report his post-retirement earnings as an employee of a third party.”

Blog:

J.Tyler’s public comments are disingenuous.

The CalSTRS audit is indisputable in its findings that the college did not follow state law. The Giese administration did not ensure that MSJC report his post-retirement earnings, and the law required them to do so. According to the audit, both Giese and Tyler (Human Resource Dept.) were notified by CalSTRS as early as August 2005 in the matter and did not comply.? The college was the “system of reporting that did not follow the Ed Code Sections.”

J. Tyler has no credibility in my opinion and all information provided by him is suspect to his misinterpretation or purposeful disinformation to mislead the public.

MSJC has $104.5 million dollars budget/PE

Friday, September 14th, 2007

http://www.pe.com/localnews/inland/stories/PE_News_Local_H_budget14.3f1ef71.html

The article by Jamie Ayala, ran in todays PE. It does not adequently disclose the tone and culture of the meeting concerning the discussion of the resolution to authorize a bond proposal and the 3-2 vote by the board, with McGargill, Motte, opposed.

“Greg Barker, a Beaumont real estate broker who is running against board President Eugene Kadow in the upcoming college board member election, voiced concerns about taxing residents. He said he supported a new campus in the area, but believed that capturing state funds was the better route to building one.”

Barker spoke publicly after board chair Eugene Kadow’s newly organized “Friends of MSJC” spoke in support of the bond proposal for building the Banning campus. There was heated discussion between Motte and Kadow regarding the CPEC approval process to ensure state operational funding and state capital construction funding for the proposed campus. Kadow disagreed, indicating the CPEC approval and application process was premature and would be taken at a later date, i.e., “after he taxes property owners”.

Blog:

Kadow thinks he is more knowledgeable than the state in how to build community college campuses. His acrimony towards those with opposing views is quite apparent. Trustees Sparkman and Schlange asked no questions, verbally supporting the resolution to authorize a tax on property owners in the Pass area.

“Thumbs down” to reporter, Jamie Ayala. She missed the real story. Was she sleeping?

CPEC Report 02-6: Guidelines for Review of Proposed University Campuses, Community Colleges and Educational Joint Use Centers

Wednesday, September 12th, 2007

http://www.cpec.ca.gov/Publications/ReportSummary.ASP?Report=1050

The above CPEC report clarifies the comprehensive process involved in attaining state approvals to build a new community college campus/center or a joint use educational facility.

The review process: “The State’s review process not only helps to ensure that new campuses and off-campus centers develop in accordance with statewide needs and segmental long-range planning goals, but also helps to ensure that State capital outlay funds will be wisely spent.”

“Each review plays an important role in ensuring that the proposed institution meets specific needs, will be financially viable, will offer high quality educational services, and will have enrollments sufficient to sustain the project in the long-term.”

Blog:

Kadows’ plan to tax local voters for an unapproved site does not ensure that public funds will be wisely spent.

Pass residents passed over by MSJC

Wednesday, September 12th, 2007

http://www.pe.com/columns/bobpratte/stories/PE_News_Local_B_bbob12.61217c.html

This column by Bob Pratte, of the Press Enterprise makes a good point. Anyone from the Pass area that feels “passed over by MSJC” needs to hold MSJC Board Chair, Eugene Kadow accountable. Kadow and the board majority were counting on the $720,000,000 failed bond of 2006 to cover the costs of this campus.

The fact is, Eugene Kadow as Board Chair has done no further due diligence on the Banning proposed site for CPEC approvals for state funding for capital construction and operational funding since the site purchase in 2003. That said…..now, with Kadow up for re-election, he has somehow convinced a group of “Friends of MSJC” and the Banning Chamber to go forward on the site and form a tax assessment district for a local bond to build the campus. If this goes forward, local taxpayers will build an unapproved campus which will not qualify for state funded operational revenues.

None of this sounds smart to me. Build it the “old way”, incrementally over time with state bonds. Earn it, with qualifying growth enrollments and population figures.

Why tax local property owners for local bonds when voters passed Prop 1 D, 2006, in the amount of $10.4 billion for CPEC approved sites, centers and campuses?

Share This

Posted in Ann Motte, News | 1 Comment »

MSJC trustees consider local bond for Banning campus/PE

Wednesday, September 12th, 2007

http://www.pe.com/localnews/inland/stories/PE_News_Local_H_funds12.3daf6ed.html#

The article by Jamie Ayala ran in today’s newspaper. What it doesn’t tell the reader is critical.

“The property has been sitting idle, waiting for the dollars to come in so we can build it.” Eugene Kadow

“While the property sits barren, the college has tried to build enrollment in the area to demonstrate a critical mass of students, a requirement to qualify for state building funds.” Eugene Kadow

Blog:

Why tax local property owners for local bonds when state bonds are available to build campuses?

Voters passed Proposition 1 D, November 2006, in the amount of 10.4 Billions dollars for Kindergarten - Higher Education. Of the 10.4 Billion in state bonds authorized by the voters, 3 Billion was for Community College Districts.

A community college center or campus can be built with state bonds incrementally over time, just as MSJC has built the Menifee campus. The state has a comprehensive formula based upon student enrollment growth to qualify for new state funded capital construction projects. A community college campus must be CPEC approved to receive state bonds for construction and operational funding.

The college has not been “trying to build enrollment in the area”. If this were true, high schools in Banning and Beaumont would be offering increased class sections. Banning has no college offerings and Beaumont has 12-18 sections. This is election hype. Kadow wants you to think he has done lots of work. He hasn’t.

Voters beware. Kadow doesn’t want to compete for state bonds.? Kadow? is “waiting for the dollars to come in so we can build it.” i.e., your wallet.
